Class CompletionEndpoint

Text generation is the core function of the API. You give the API a prompt, and it generates a completion. The way you “program” the API to do a task is by simply describing the task in plain english or providing a few written examples. This simple approach works for a wide range of use cases, including summarization, translation, grammar correction, question answering, chatbots, composing emails, and much more (see the prompt library for inspiration).

Properties

| Improve this Doc View Source

DefaultCompletionRequestArgs

This allows you to set default parameters for every request, for example to set a default temperature or max tokens. For every request, if you do not have a parameter set on the request but do have it set here as a default, the request will automatically pick up the default value.

Declaration
public CompletionRequest DefaultCompletionRequestArgs { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
CompletionRequest
| Improve this Doc View Source

Endpoint

The name of the endpoint, which is the final path segment in the API URL. For example, "completions".

Declaration
protected override string Endpoint { get; }

CreateCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest)

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified request. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result.

Declaration
public async Task<CompletionResult> CreateCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest request)
Parameters
Type Name Description
CompletionRequest request

The request to send to the API. This does not fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs.
Returns
Type Description
System.Threading.Tasks.Task<CompletionResult>

Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its Completions property for the completions.
| Improve this Doc View Source

CreateCompletionAsync(String, Model, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Boolean>, String[])

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified parameters. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs if present.

Declaration
public Task<CompletionResult> CreateCompletionAsync(string prompt, Model model = null, int? max_tokens = null, double? temperature = null, double? top_p = null, int? numOutputs = null, double? presencePenalty = null, double? frequencyPenalty = null, int? logProbs = null, bool? echo = null, params string[] stopSequences)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String prompt

The prompt to generate from
Model model

The model to use. You can use GetModelsAsync() to see all of your available models, or use a standard model like DavinciText.
System.Nullable<System.Int32> max_tokens

How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.
System.Nullable<System.Double> temperature

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or top_p but not both.
System.Nullable<System.Double> top_p

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or temperature but not both.
System.Nullable<System.Int32> numOutputs

How many different choices to request for each prompt.
System.Nullable<System.Double> presencePenalty

The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
System.Nullable<System.Double> frequencyPenalty

The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
System.Nullable<System.Int32> logProbs

Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, which can be found in Completions -> Logprobs. So for example, if logprobs is 10, the API will return a list of the 10 most likely tokens. If logprobs is supplied, the API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response.
System.Nullable<System.Boolean> echo

Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion.
System.String[] stopSequences

One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
Returns
Type Description
System.Threading.Tasks.Task<CompletionResult>

Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its Completions property for the completions.
| Improve this Doc View Source

CreateCompletionAsync(String[])

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified promptes, with other paramets being drawn from default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs if present. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result.

Declaration
public Task<CompletionResult> CreateCompletionAsync(params string[] prompts)

One or more prompts to generate from
Returns
Type Description

CreateCompletionsAsync(CompletionRequest, Int32)

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified request and a requested number of outputs. This is non-streaming, so it will wait until the API returns the full result.

Declaration
public Task<CompletionResult> CreateCompletionsAsync(CompletionRequest request, int numOutputs = 5)
Parameters
Type Name Description
CompletionRequest request

The request to send to the API. This does not fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs.
System.Int32 numOutputs

Overrides NumChoicesPerPrompt as a convenience.
Returns
Type Description
System.Threading.Tasks.Task<CompletionResult>

Asynchronously returns the completion result. Look in its Completions property for the completions, which should have a length equal to numOutputs.

StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest, Action<CompletionResult>)

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified request, and stream the results to the resultHandler as they come in. If you are on the latest C# supporting async enumerables, you may prefer the cleaner syntax of StreamCompletionEnumerableAsync(CompletionRequest) instead.

Declaration
public async Task StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest request, Action<CompletionResult> resultHandler)
Parameters
Type Name Description
CompletionRequest request

The request to send to the API. This does not fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs.
System.Action<CompletionResult> resultHandler

An action to be called as each new result arrives.
Returns
Type Description
System.Threading.Tasks.Task
| Improve this Doc View Source

StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest, Action<Int32, CompletionResult>)

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified request, and stream the results to the resultHandler as they come in. If you are on the latest C# supporting async enumerables, you may prefer the cleaner syntax of StreamCompletionEnumerableAsync(CompletionRequest) instead.

Declaration
public async Task StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest request, Action<int, CompletionResult> resultHandler)
Parameters
Type Name Description
CompletionRequest request

The request to send to the API. This does not fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs.
System.Action<System.Int32, CompletionResult> resultHandler

An action to be called as each new result arrives, which includes the index of the result in the overall result set.
Returns
Type Description
System.Threading.Tasks.Task
| Improve this Doc View Source

StreamCompletionEnumerableAsync(CompletionRequest)

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified request, and stream the results as they come in. If you are not using C# 8 supporting async enumerables or if you are using the .NET Framework, you may need to use StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest, Action<CompletionResult>) instead.

Declaration
public IAsyncEnumerable<CompletionResult> StreamCompletionEnumerableAsync(CompletionRequest request)
Parameters
Type Name Description
CompletionRequest request

The request to send to the API. This does not fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs.
Returns
Type Description
System.Collections.Generic.IAsyncEnumerable<CompletionResult>

An async enumerable with each of the results as they come in. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/whats-new/csharp-8#asynchronous-streams for more details on how to consume an async enumerable.
| Improve this Doc View Source

StreamCompletionEnumerableAsync(String, Model, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Double>, Nullable<Int32>, Nullable<Boolean>, String[])

Ask the API to complete the prompt(s) using the specified parameters. Any non-specified parameters will fall back to default values specified in DefaultCompletionRequestArgs if present. If you are not using C# 8 supporting async enumerables or if you are using the .NET Framework, you may need to use StreamCompletionAsync(CompletionRequest, Action<CompletionResult>) instead.
